maml:description.maml:para: Adds a group into a Group Policy Object

Use this function to add a group into a Group Policy Object. First you have to create a new group definition object using New-GPPGroup. This function is useful if you want to add the same group definition into several Group Policy objects. If you just want to create a single group and add it into a GPO immediately, you can just use the -GPOName/GPOId parameter at New-GPPGroup.
Specifies which Group Policy context to use: Machine or User. Doesn't do anything right now, since the User one has not yet been implemented.
Specifies a Group Policy object ID into which you want to add a group. It is a name of a Group Policy's object in Active Directory. Look into a CN=Policies,CN=System container in your AD DS domain.
Specifies an object of a group definition which you want to add into a GPO. You can create one with New-GPPGroup.
Specifies which Group Policy context to use: Machine or User. Doesn't do anything right now, since the User one has not yet been implemented.
Specifies a Group Policy object name into which you want to add a group.
Specifies an object of a group definition which you want to add into a GPO. You can create one with New-GPPGroup.
Specifies which Group Policy context to use: Machine or User. Doesn't do anything right now, since the User one has not yet been implemented.
Specifies a Group Policy object ID into which you want to add a group. It is a name of a Group Policy's object in Active Directory. Look into a CN=Policies,CN=System container in your AD DS domain.
Specifies a Group Policy object name into which you want to add a group.
Specifies an object of a group definition which you want to add into a GPO. You can create one with New-GPPGroup.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Adds a group object $GroupObject into a Group Policy named TEST.
Adds a group definition object $GroupObject into a Group Policy by using its ID (see the description for the -GPOId parameter below).

maml:description.maml:para: Adds a member into a group already existing in a GPO object.
Adds a member into a group already existing in a GPO object. Use New-GPPGroupMember to create group members.
Specifies which Group Policy context to use: Machine or User. Doesn't do anything right now, since the User one has not yet been implemented.
Specifies the ID of a GPO where the target group is. It is a name of a Group Policy's object in Active Directory. Look into a CN=Policies,CN=System container in your AD DS domain.

Specifies the UID of a target group. UID is a unique identifier of an object in GPP. You can have several groups with the same Name/SID combination in the same Group Policy object - those groups will have different UIDs. You may get a UID of a group by looking at its "uid" property.
Specifies a member object to add. Use New-GPPGroupMember to create one.
Specifies which Group Policy context to use: Machine or User. Doesn't do anything right now, since the User one has not yet been implemented.
Specifies the ID of a GPO where the target group is. It is a name of a Group Policy's object in Active Directory. Look into a CN=Policies,CN=System container in your AD DS domain.
Specifies the SID of a target group.
Specifies a member object to add. Use New-GPPGroupMember to create one.
Specifies which Group Policy context to use: Machine or User. Doesn't do anything right now, since the User one has not yet been implemented.
Specifies the ID of a GPO where the target group is. It is a name of a Group Policy's object in Active Directory. Look into a CN=Policies,CN=System container in your AD DS domain.
Specifies the name of a target group.
Specifies a member object to add. Use New-GPPGroupMember to create one.
Specifies which Group Policy context to use: Machine or User. Doesn't do anything right now, since the User one has not yet been implemented.
Specifies the name of a GPO where the target group is.

Specifies the UID of a target group. UID is a unique identifier of an object in GPP. You can have several groups with the same Name/SID combination in the same Group Policy object - those groups will have different UIDs. You may get a UID of a group by looking at its "uid" property.
Specifies a member object to add. Use New-GPPGroupMember to create one.
Specifies which Group Policy context to use: Machine or User. Doesn't do anything right now, since the User one has not yet been implemented.
Specifies the name of a GPO where the target group is.
Specifies the SID of a target group.
Specifies a member object to add. Use New-GPPGroupMember to create one.
Specifies which Group Policy context to use: Machine or User. Doesn't do anything right now, since the User one has not yet been implemented.
Specifies the name of a GPO where the target group is.
Specifies the name of a target group.
Specifies a member object to add. Use New-GPPGroupMember to create one.
Specifies which Group Policy context to use: Machine or User. Doesn't do anything right now, since the User one has not yet been implemented.
Specifies the ID of a GPO where the target group is. It is a name of a Group Policy's object in Active Directory. Look into a CN=Policies,CN=System container in your AD DS domain.
Specifies the name of a GPO where the target group is.
Specifies the name of a target group.
Specifies the SID of a target group.

Specifies the UID of a target group. UID is a unique identifier of an object in GPP. You can have several groups with the same Name/SID combination in the same Group Policy object - those groups will have different UIDs. You may get a UID of a group by looking at its "uid" property.
Specifies a member object to add. Use New-GPPGroupMember to create one.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Member = New-GPPGroupMember -Name 'EXAMPLE\Administrator' -Action REMOVE PS C:\> Add-GPPGroupMember -InputObject $Member -GroupName 'EXAMPLE\TEST' -GPOName 'Custom Group Policy'

dev:remarks.maml:para: Adds a user "Administrator" into all groups named "EXAMPLE\TEST" defined in the "Custom Group Policy" GPO. The user will be REMOVED from this group on computers to which the GPO applies.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Member = New-GPPGroupMember -Name 'EXAMPLE\Administrator' -Action REMOVE PS C:\> Add-GPPGroupMember -InputObject $Member -GroupUID '3B1BF433-38BF-47A5-925C-3DC32B6555B3' -GPOId '70f86590-588a-4659-8880-3d2374604811'

dev:remarks.maml:para: Adds a user "Administrator" into a group with the UID "3B1BF433-38BF-47A5-925C-3DC32B6555B3" defined in a GPO with the ID "70f86590-588a-4659-8880-3d2374604811". The user will be REMOVED from this group on computers to which the GPO applies.

maml:description.maml:para: Retrieves a group from a given Group Policy Preferences instance.

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new Group Policy Preferences group definition.
Creates a new Group Policy Preferences group definition. You can either save it in the memory for additional processing or immediately put into a GPO by using the -GPOName or -GPOId parameters.
Note that available parameters depend on the action you choose: -Create, -Replace, -Update, or -Delete. This mimics the GUI behavior.
Specifies which Group Policy context to use: Machine or User. Doesn't do anything right now, since the User one has not yet been implemented.
Sets the action property of the group definition to "Delete".

Specifies the ID of a GPO into which you want to add the newly created group definition. It is a name of a Group Policy's object in Active Directory. Look into a CN=Policies,CN=System container in your AD DS domain.
Specifies the name of a group.

Sets the description of a group object.
Disables processing of this group object. In the GUI you'll see it greyed out.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Members = New-GPPGroupMember -SID 'S-1-5-21-2571216883-1601522099-2002488368-500' -Action REMOVE PS C:\> New-GPPGroup -Name 'TEST-1' -GPOName 'Custom Group Policy' -Create -Members $Members

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a new group definition for a group called "TEST-1" with its action set to "Create" and using $Members as members for this group. The definition is saved in a GPO called "Custom Group Policy".
Creates a new group definition for a group called "TEST-1" with its action set to "Delete", and saves it in a GPO with ID 70f86590-588a-4659-8880-3d2374604811.

Creates a new group definition with "EXAMPLE\SupportGroup" as group member and "Update" as its action. The definition specifies the group by SID rather its name. S-1-5-32-547 means "Power Users". Note that this group definition is not saved in any group policy object - it exists only in memory. You can modify it and later save in a GPO using Add-GPPGroup.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 4 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> New-GPPGroup -Name 'TEST-1' -Replace -GPOName 'Custom Group Policy' -Members @((New-GPPGroupMember -Name 'EXAMPLE\Administrator' -Action ADD),(New-GPPGroupMember -Name 'EXAMPLE\SupportGroup' -Action ADD)) -Disable

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a new group definition in a GPO named "Custom Group Policy", with "EXAMPLE\Administrator" and "EXAMPLE\SupportGroup" as group members. The group definition will be in a disabled state and its action is "Replace".

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new group member object to use in other commands later.

Creates a new group member object in memory. Use the created object in Add-GPPGroupMember, New-GPPGroup, or Set-GPPGroup. The result object MUST have both the name and SID filled, so the function resolves one through another and fails if it does not succeed.
Specifies which action should GPP engine to execute regarding this security principal: either to ADD or to REMOVE it from a group.
Specifies the name of a security principal.
Specifies which action should GPP engine to execute regarding this security principal: either to ADD or to REMOVE it from a group.
Specifies the SID of a security principal.
Specifies which action should GPP engine to execute regarding this security principal: either to ADD or to REMOVE it from a group.
Specifies the name of a security principal.
Specifies the SID of a security principal.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Uses the -Name parameter to resolve the SID of this security principal from Active Directory domain. The result object will have its action set to "ADD".
Uses the -SID parameter to resolve the name of this security principal from Active Directory domain. The result object will have its action set to "ADD".

maml:description.maml:para: Creates a new Group Policy Preferences user definition.
Creates a new Group Policy Preferences user definition. You can either save it in the memory for additional processing or immediately put into a GPO by using the -GPOName or -GPOId parameters.
Note that available parameters depend on the action you choose: -Update or -Delete. This mimics the GUI behavior.
Specifies that the target user account must be disabled.
Specifies that this user account should expire at a given date in the future. Despite that you pass a full DateTime object to this parameter, only date will be used.
Specifies which Group Policy context to use: Machine or User. Doesn't do anything right now, since the User one has not yet been implemented.
Sets the description of a user object.
Disables processing of this group object. In the GUI you'll see it greyed out.
Specifies a full name for the target account.

Specifies the ID of a GPO into which you want to add the newly created user definition. It is a name of a Group Policy's object in Active Directory. Look into a CN=Policies,CN=System container in your AD DS domain.
Specifies the name of a user.
Specifies the new name of a user if you want to rename it on target hosts.
Returns a new user definition object to the pipeline.
Sets the action property of the user definition to "Update".

Returns a new user definition object to the pipeline.
Speficies that the password of the target account should not expire.
Sets the action property of the user definition to "Update".
Specifies that the target account should not be able to change its password by itself.
Specifies that the target account must change its password at the next logon.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Creates a new user definition for a user called "TEST-1" in a GPO called "Custom Group Policy". The definition will rename this user on target computers to "TEST2"
Creates a new group definition for a user called "TEST-1" with its action set to "Delete", and saves it in a GPO with ID 70f86590-588a-4659-8880-3d2374604811.

Creates a new user definition in the current PowerShell session for a built-in user "Administrator". This object defines that "Administrator"'s will never expire. Note that this group definition is not saved in any group policy object - it exists only in memory. You can modify it and later save in a GPO using Add-GPPUser.
Creates a new user definition in a GPO named "Custom Group Policy". The definition specifies that all users named "TEST-1" on target computers should expire in a month.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Removes all groups named "TEST-*" from group "TEST" defined in the "Custom Group Policy" GPO. The -Name parameter does not support wildcards.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Members = Get-GPPGroupMember -Name 'EXAMPLE\TEST-*' -GPOName 'Custom Group Policy' PS C:\> $Members | % { Remove-GPPGroupMember -Name $_.Name -GroupSID 'S-1-5-2' -GPOName 'Custom Group Policy' }

dev:remarks.maml:para: Removes all groups which name starts with "EXAMPLE\TEST-" from a group with SID "S-1-5-2" defined in the "Custom Group Policy" GPO.

maml:description.maml:para: Sets properties of a group definition in a specified Group Policy object.

Sets properties of a group definition in a specified Group Policy object. You may also use it to write a group definition object from memory into a GPO and changing some of its properties in the process. If you want just to add a group definition into a GPO, w/o any modifications, I suggest you to use Add-GPPGroup.

Sets one of four actions which you can instruct the GPP engine to do with a group: Create, Replace, Update, or Delete. Different actions have different sets of allowed parameters. The function initially does not restrict you from pass parameters incompatible with Action, but will correct them to be in accordance with the action. i.e. if you set -Action to "Delete" and -NewName to something, -NewName will be ignored. Also, if you have a group object with some properties defined and change its action to "Delete", the object will be stripped off its properties. Same concept applies to other actions as well.
For properties compatibility see help for New-GPPGroup.
Specifies which Group Policy context to use: Machine or User. Doesn't do anything right now, since the User one has not yet been implemented.
Sets the DeleteAllGroups attribute at the group object.
Sets the DeleteAllUsers attribute at the group object.
Sets the description of a group object.
Disables processing of this group definition. In the GUI you'll see it greyed out.
Specifies the ID of a GPO in which you want to search for groups. It is a name of a Group Policy's object in Active Directory. Look into a CN=Policies,CN=System container in your AD DS domain.
If you already have a group definition object in memory, which you want to write into a Group Policy, you can pass in into this parameter.
Specifies which group members should be set for this group. Use New-GPPGroupMember to create them.
Specifies a new name for a group if you want to rename it on target hosts.
Returns a new group definition object to the pipeline.

Specifies the SID of a group which you want to change.

Sets one of four actions which you can instruct the GPP engine to do with a group: Create, Replace, Update, or Delete. Different actions have different sets of allowed parameters. The function initially does not restrict you from pass parameters incompatible with Action, but will correct them to be in accordance with the action. i.e. if you set -Action to "Delete" and -NewName to something, -NewName will be ignored. Also, if you have a group object with some properties defined and change its action to "Delete", the object will be stripped off its properties. Same concept applies to other actions as well.
For properties compatibility see help for New-GPPGroup.
Specifies which Group Policy context to use: Machine or User. Doesn't do anything right now, since the User one has not yet been implemented.
Sets the DeleteAllGroups attribute at the group object.
Sets the DeleteAllUsers attribute at the group object.
Sets the description of a group object.
Disables processing of this group definition. In the GUI you'll see it greyed out.
Specifies the ID of a GPO in which you want to search for groups. It is a name of a Group Policy's object in Active Directory. Look into a CN=Policies,CN=System container in your AD DS domain.
Specifies the name of a GPO in which you want to search for groups.
If you already have a group definition object in memory, which you want to write into a Group Policy, you can pass in into this parameter.
Specifies which group members should be set for this group. Use New-GPPGroupMember to create them.
Specifies the name of a group which you want to change. Supports wildcards.
Specifies a new name for a group if you want to rename it on target hosts.
Returns a new group definition object to the pipeline.
Specifies the SID of a group which you want to change.
Specifies the name of a group which you want to change. Does not support wildcards.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-GPPGroup -SID 'S-1-5-32-544' -GPOName 'Custom Group Policy' -Action Update -Members $Members

dev:remarks.maml:para: Changes the action of the group definition of a group with SID "S-1-5-32-544" in the GPO "Custom Group Policy" to "Update" and sets it members to the value of the $Members variable.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-GPPGroup -Name 'EXAMPLE\Test-Group' -GPOName 'Custom Group Policy' -Action Delete

dev:remarks.maml:para: Changes the action of the group definition of a group called "EXAMPLE\Test-Group" in the GPO "Custom Group Policy" to "Delete".

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Group = Get-GPPGroup -Name 'EXAMPLE\Test-Group' -GPOName 'Custom Group Policy' PS C:\> Set-GPPGroup -InputObject $Group -GPOName 'Custom Group Policy' -DeleteAllGroups -DeleteAllUsers

dev:remarks.maml:para: Updates the definition of the "EXAMPLE\Test-Group" group in the "Custom Group Policy" GPO to delete all group and users from that group except for those explicitly defined in the group definition.
Disables the group definition for a group called "EXAMPLE\Test-Group" in the "Custom Group Policy" GPO.

maml:description.maml:para: Sets properties of a group member defined in a Group Policy object.
Sets properties of a group member defined in a Group Policy object. Well, actually the only property you can change is "Action" - there's just not much to set.
Specifies which action should GPP engine to execute regarding this security principal: either to ADD or to REMOVE it from a group.
Specifies which Group Policy context to use: Machine or User. Doesn't do anything right now, since the User one has not yet been implemented.
Specifies the ID of a GPO in which you want to search for groups. It is a name of a Group Policy's object in Active Directory. Look into a CN=Policies,CN=System container in your AD DS domain.

Specifies the UID of a group in which you want to change a member. A UID is a unique identifier of an object in GPP. You can have several groups with the same Name/SID combination in the same Group Policy object - those groups will have different UIDs. You may get a UID of a group by looking at its "uid" property.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 1 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-GPPGroupMember -Name 'EXAMPLE\Administrator' -Action ADD -GroupName 'Administrators (built-in)' -GPOName 'Custom Group Policy'

dev:remarks.maml:para: Sets the action to ADD for the "EXAMPLE\Administrator" user in the "Administrators (built-in)" group in a group policy named "Custom Group Policy".

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 2 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-GPPGroupMember -Name 'EXAMPLE\Administrator' -Action REMOVE -GroupSID 'S-1-5-32-544' -GPOName 'Custom Group Policy'

dev:remarks.maml:para: Sets the action to REMOVE for the "EXAMPLE\Administrator" user in a group with the SID S-1-5-32-544 a group policy named "Custom Group Policy".

maml:description.maml:para: Sets properties of a user definition in a specified Group Policy object.

Sets properties of a user definition in a specified Group Policy object. You may also use it to write a user definition object from memory into a GPO and changing some of its properties in the process. If you want just to add a user definition into a GPO, w/o any modifications, I suggest you to use Add-GPPUser.
Specifies that the target user account must be disabled.
Specifies that this user account should expire at a given date in the future. Despite that you pass a full DateTime object to this parameter, only date will be used.

Sets one of two actions which you can instruct the GPP engine to do with a user: Update or Delete. Different actions have different sets of allowed parameters. The function initially does not restrict you from pass parameters incompatible with Action, but will correct them to be in accordance with the action. i.e. if you set -Action to "Delete" and -NewName to something, -NewName will be ignored. Also, if you have a user object with some properties defined and change its action to "Delete", the object will be stripped off its properties.
For properties compatibility see help for New-GPPUser.
Allows you to target your user definition to a system built-in user, instead of a regular account.
Specifies which Group Policy context to use: Machine or User. Doesn't do anything right now, since the User one has not yet been implemented.
Sets the description of a user object.
Disables processing of this group definition. In the GUI you'll see it greyed out.
Specifies a full name for the target account.
Specifies the ID of a GPO in which you want to search for users. It is a name of a Group Policy's object in Active Directory. Look into a CN=Policies,CN=System container in your AD DS domain.
Specifies a new name for a user if you want to rename it on target hosts.
Returns a new user definition object to the pipeline.
Specifies that the target account must change its password at the next logon.
Specifies that the target user account must be disabled.
Specifies that this user account should expire at a given date in the future. Despite that you pass a full DateTime object to this parameter, only date will be used.

Specifies that the target account must change its password at the next logon.
Specifies that the target user account must be disabled.
Specifies that this user account should expire at a given date in the future. Despite that you pass a full DateTime object to this parameter, only date will be used.

Sets one of two actions which you can instruct the GPP engine to do with a user: Update or Delete. Different actions have different sets of allowed parameters. The function initially does not restrict you from pass parameters incompatible with Action, but will correct them to be in accordance with the action. i.e. if you set -Action to "Delete" and -NewName to something, -NewName will be ignored. Also, if you have a user object with some properties defined and change its action to "Delete", the object will be stripped off its properties.

dev:remarks.maml:para: For a user called "TEST-1" in the "Custom Group Policy" GPO sets that on target computers this user must be renamed to "TEST2"
Specifies that a user called "TEST-1" must be deleted from all target computers, and saves these instructions in a GPO with ID 70f86590-588a-4659-8880-3d2374604811.

command:example.maml:title: -------------------------- Example 3 --------------------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $User = Get-GPPUser -Name 'TEST-1' -GPOName 'Custom Group Policy' PS C:\> Set-GPPUser -InputObject $User -GPOName 'Custom Group Policy' -PasswordNeverExpires $true

dev:remarks.maml:para: Retrieves a user definition from a GPO called "Custom Group Policy" and then saves it back, but with an option to never-ever change their password.
